articles.headline: Obama Report Outlines Talks on Senate Seat
articles.snippet: An Obama confidante’s contact with a labor union official could be of interest to prosecutors, but a report found that no Obama aides talked about a quid pro quo.
articles.abstract: An Obama confidante’s contact with a labor union official could be of interest to prosecutors, but a report found that no Obama aides talked about a quid pro quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU  In the days after Barack Obama’s election as president, Rahm Emanuel, a top adviser, suggested to Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois that Mr. Obama’s Senate seat should be filled by Valerie Jarrett, a confidante of Mr. Obama.

articles.headline: Turning Page, E-Books Start to Take Hold
articles.snippet: Thanks in part to the popularity of Amazon.com’s wireless Kindle device, the e-book has started to take hold.
articles.abstract: Thanks in part to the popularity of Amazon.com’s wireless Kindle device, the e-book has started to take hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could book lovers finally be willing to switch from paper to pixels?
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Settles 63 Lawsuits Over Wages
articles.snippet: The retailer said it will pay from $352 million to $640 million to settle lawsuits over wages and work rules.
articles.abstract: The retailer said it will pay from $352 million to $640 million to settle lawsuits over wages and work rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart said on Tuesday that it would pay at least $352 million, and possibly far more, to settle lawsuits across the country claiming that it forced employees to work off the clock. Several lawyers described it as the largest settlement ever for lawsuits over wage violations.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Stephanie Rosenbloom

articles.headline: Jordanian Students Rebel, Embracing Conservative Islam
articles.snippet: Across the Middle East, young people are using religion to defy the status quo and challenge their governments.
articles.abstract: Across the Middle East, young people are using religion to defy the status quo and challenge their governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Muhammad Fawaz is a very serious college junior with a stern gaze and a reluctant smile that barely cloaks suppressed anger. He never wanted to attend Jordan University. He hates spending hours each day commuting.

articles.headline: Insights Both Fresh and Tested
articles.snippet: In keeping with an unusual year, this column’s annual list of the economics books of the year is going to be a little unorthodox.
articles.abstract: In keeping with an unusual year, this column’s annual list of the economics books of the year is going to be a little unorthodox.
articles.lead_paragraph: In keeping with an unusual year, this column’s annual list of the economics books of the year is going to be a little unorthodox.

articles.headline: Nearly the End of the Line for S.U.V.’s
articles.snippet: Even a bailout could not save three of the last remaining plants in the U.S. still making sport utility vehicles.
articles.abstract: Even a bailout could not save three of the last remaining plants in the U.S. still making sport utility vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Even a federal bailout could not save three of the last remaining plants in the United States still making sport utility vehicles.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Mexican Shoppers Go North, Seeking Bargains
articles.snippet: Middle- and upper-income families are traveling hundreds of miles to purchase a much wider selection of products at substantially lower prices than can be found in their hometowns.
articles.abstract: Middle- and upper-income families are traveling hundreds of miles to purchase a much wider selection of products at substantially lower prices than can be found in their hometowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Mexican shoppers with fists full of cash and long Christmas lists are pouring across the border into hotels, restaurants and shopping malls here, providing an economic boost in a downward spiraling economy.

articles.headline: Afghans and U.S. Plan to Recruit Local Militias
articles.snippet: American commanders and Afghan leaders hope to imitate Iraq’s successful experiment, but there are fears it could prompt further bloodletting.
articles.abstract: American commanders and Afghan leaders hope to imitate Iraq’s successful experiment, but there are fears it could prompt further bloodletting.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taking a page from the successful experiment in Iraq, American commanders and Afghan leaders are preparing to arm local militias to help in the fight against a resurgent Taliban. But along with hope, the move is raising fears here that the new armed groups could push the country into a deeper bloodletting.

articles.headline: Madoff Dealings Tarnish a Private Swiss Bank
articles.snippet: L’Affaire Madoff, as it has become known, has raised questions why Union Bancaire Privée did not look more closely at its returns.
articles.abstract: L’Affaire Madoff, as it has become known, has raised questions why Union Bancaire Privée did not look more closely at its returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  For generations, the calling card of Swiss private bankers has been the promise of prudence and discretion.
